data.title: Barry Gibb: ‘I’m the eldest. I should have gone first. I have survivor’s guilt’
data.meta_description: Glastonbury 2017 was, says Barry Gibb, “the greatest night of my life, no question”. Occupying Sunday’s “Legends” slot on the Pyramid Stage, the 70-year old mus
data.text:
Glastonbury 2017 was, says Barry Gibb, “the greatest night of my life, no question”. Occupying Sunday’s “Legends” slot on the Pyramid Stage, the 70-year old musician treated the audience (an audience sporting tribute beards, teeth and gold lamé bomber jackets) to an anthemic roll call of Bee Gees classics – Tragedy, Stayin’ Alive and Night Fever – a full 40 years after the film Saturday Night Fever, whose soundtrack sent the band stratospheric and cemented their place in the annals of pop.

When the crowd, in unison, crooned along to the ballad Words, its creator, centre stage, fell silent in awe. “I just didn’t know people really cared that much,” he says today, still apparently baffled by the adulation. “And after we
